channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: One Family. Six Decades. Myriad Views of Fidel Castro’s Revolution.
item.media:description: Fidel Castro after arriving in Havana on Jan. 8, 1959. Mr. Castro’s revolution was welcomed by Cubans like Juan Montes Torre, a poor laborer at the time. “It was an emotional shock,” Mr. Montes recalled. “These bearded men, poorly dressed — they won! And on behalf of the lower classes!”
item.description: The clash of emotions common in Cuban families is reflected in a grandfather’s loyalty to Mr. Castro and a granddaughter’s glum view of conditions in her country.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Donald Trump’s Threat to Close Door Reopens Old Wounds in Cuba
item.media:description: President Obama met with the Cuban president, Raúl Castro, in Havana in March.
item.description: In a post on Twitter, he said he would “terminate” the pact President Obama made if Cuba is unwilling to make “a better deal for the Cuban people.”
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE, AZAM AHMED and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Subdued Cuba Prepares Memorial for Castro
item.description: A two-day memorial and a period of “Duelo Nacional,” or national mourning, will offer Cubans a chance to pay their respects to the longtime leader.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Little Fidel in All of Us
item.media:description: People in Miami reacting to the news of the death of Fidel Castro.
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.description: Who would any of us be if he hadn’t rearranged our destinies and caused this rupture in our lives?
item.dc:creator: ACHY OBEJAS

item.title: Fidel Castro, Cuban Revolutionary Who Defied U.S., Dies at 90
item.media:description: Fidel Castro was seen as a ruthless despot by some and hailed as a revolutionary hero by others.
item.description: Mr. Castro brought the Cold War to the Western Hemisphere, bedeviled 11 American presidents and briefly pushed the world to the brink of nuclear war.
item.dc:creator: ANTHONY DePALMA

item.title: For Bashar al-Assad, Winning the Syrian War May Lead to New Troubles
item.media:description: Forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on top of a building overlooking Aleppo on Monday during their assault to retake the city from rebel fighters. They made large territorial gains Monday.
item.description: If the Syrian president defeats the rebels, he may preside over an economic wasteland hampered by a low-level insurgency and facing a challenge to find financial aid to rebuild.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: ‘Trump Effect’ Is Already Shaping Events Around the World
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at an American Israel Public Affairs Committee conference in Washington in March. The political right in Israel has openly celebrated his election as president.
item.description: Donald J. Trump’s election is influencing markets, currencies and government policies as the world bets on how he will rewrite international rules.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: A Forgotten Step in Saving African Wildlife: Protecting the Rangers
item.media:description: David Piroris, left, and Solomon Ngila of the Lewa Wildlife Conservancy’s antipoaching dog unit in Kenya, training Maxo.
item.description: Many park personnel, responsible for fending off poachers, go without basic necessities like boots, tents and health insurance. Some groups are trying to change that.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER

item.title: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa Faces Leadership Challenge
item.media:description: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa, shown during the opening of parliament last year in Cape Town, has been embroiled in one scandal after another since taking office in 2009.
item.description: The African National Congress’s national executive committee introduced, for the first time, a motion urging the embattled Mr. Zuma to step down.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: The Interpreter: How Stable Are Democracies? ‘Warning Signs Are Flashing Red’
item.media:credit: Yascha Mounk and Roberto Stefan Foa, “The Signs of Democratic Deconsolidation,” Journal of Democracy
item.description: New research tries to spot the collapse of liberal democracies before they happen, and it suggests that Western democracy may be seriously ill.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Mark Taimanov, World-Class Chess and Piano Player, Dies at 90
item.media:description: Mark Taimanov playing in the quarterfinals of a 1971 chess tournament, which he lost to Bobby Fischer, who was at his height.
item.description: Mr. Taimanov was a classical pianist and former Soviet chess champion whose lopsided loss to Bobby Fischer in 1971 cost him his government salary.
item.dc:creator: DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

item.title: Park Geun-hye, Embattled South Korean President, Says She’s Willing to Resign
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea at the presidential Blue House in Seoul, the capital, last year. Opposition parties had planned to call for a vote Friday in Parliament on whether to impeach Ms. Park.
item.description: Ms. Park, whose administration has been embroiled in a corruption scandal, said she would let the National Assembly decide when she should step down.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Larung Gar Journal: China Takes a Chain Saw to a Center of Tibetan Buddhism
item.media:description: A Buddhist nun with a prayer wheel in Larung Gar, a monastic camp where thousands of nuns and monks live and study, in Sichuan Province, China.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: In Larung Gar, the world’s largest Buddhist institute, demolition teams are cutting through an extraordinary vista of hand-built red dwellings.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: What in the World: Germany Gleefully Leads List of World’s Top Recyclers
item.media:description: Recycling bins for glass bottles — both clear and colored — in Potsdam, Germany.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Germans sort 65 percent of their waste into an array of color-coded bins.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development

item.title: ‘Thunderstorm Asthma’ Kills 8 in Australia
item.media:description: Jill Hennessy, Victoria State’s minister for health and ambulance services, said the outbreak of severe asthma took the government by surprise.
item.description: About 8,500 people went to the hospital after a storm last week spread ryegrass seed fragments, so fine they could be inhaled, throughout the Melbourne area.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Al Jazeera Film Critical of Egyptian Army Strains Egypt-Qatar Ties Further
item.media:description: Sameh Shoukry, the foreign minister of Egypt.
item.description: The documentary, broadcast on a network owned by the Qatari government, accuses Egypt of abusing its recruits, and the country was quick to denounce it.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Houthis, in Surprise Move, Form a Government in Yemen
item.description: The announcement angered the movement’s Saudi-backed rivals and threatened diplomatic efforts to end a conflict that has ravaged Yemen for nearly two years.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Amid Flames and Suspicions in Israel, Acts of Jewish-Arab Cooperation
item.media:description: Residents whose home was destroyed by a fire in the Jewish settlement of Halamish in the West Bank.
item.description: The wildfires that swept across Israel’s countryside last week brought suspicion of arson, but also an outpouring of Jewish-Arab cooperation.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Women in Canadian Military Report Widespread Sexual Assault
item.media:description: Gen. Jonathan Vance, chief of the Canadian defense staff, speaking on Monday about a report showing that more than a quarter of women in the Canadian military have been sexually assaulted during their careers.
item.description: A survey commissioned by the armed forces puts hard numbers on a 2015 report that showed a culture hostile toward women and other minorities.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: A Headless Corpse, a Territorial Dispute and a Happy Ending
item.media:description: The signing of the land swap agreement between Belgium and the Netherlands, at the Royal Palace in Amsterdam, on Monday.
item.description: The investigation into a grisly death in the Netherlands helped Belgium and its bigger Dutch neighbor resolve a property squabble that began in 1961.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Thousands Flee Aleppo, Syria, as Government Forces Advance
item.media:description: Syrians fleeing rebel-held parts of eastern Aleppo moved on Sunday toward an area controlled by Kurdish fighters.
item.description: Troops loyal to President Bashar al-Assad drove rebels out of parts of the city, sending thousands of people fleeing for their lives.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Holocaust-Themed Ice Dance in Russia Draws Condemnation
item.description: The televised act, performed by Tatiana Navka, a skater married to an aide of President Vladimir V. Putin, was based on the film “Life Is Beautiful.”
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: U.K. Independence Party Picks Paul Nuttall to Replace Nigel Farage as Leader
item.description: Mr. Nuttall, a European Parliament member for the conflicted, anti-immigration party, is taking a job that many others have been unwilling or unable to hold.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Space’s Trash Collector? A Japanese Entrepreneur Wants the Job
item.media:description: A vacuum chamber used to test parts of Astroscale’s IDEA OSG 1 satellite at the company’s factory in Tokyo. The satellite, scheduled to be launched next year, will compile data on the density of space debris.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: A start-up company called Astroscale is dedicated to cleaning up some of humanity’s hardest-to-reach rubbish, and its plans include a small satellite with an adhesive glue.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Aquarium on Ice, a Lure for Skaters in Japan, Appalls Them Instead
item.media:description: Space World said it would hold a memorial service for the fish.
item.media:credit: The Yomiuri Shimbun, via Associated Press
item.description: A Japanese theme park tried to draw visitors by freezing 5,000 fish beneath its ice rink, but a public outcry forced it to close the attraction after just two weeks.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Amid Scandal, South Korean Officials Retreat on Controversial Textbook Plan
item.media:description: Taking a college entrance exam at a high school in Seoul, South Korea, this month. The Education Ministry has wavered on an earlier decision to require middle and high schools to use only state-issued history books.
item.description: President Park Geun-hye’s government is backing away from insisting on the use of only state-issued textbooks that critics say play down darker aspects of recent history.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Fidel Castro’s Sister, an Outspoken Critic, Takes No Joy in His Death
item.media:description: Juanita Castro at a demonstration against her brother, Fidel Castro, headed to the United Nations in October 1979, as he was preparing to address delegates there.
item.description: Juanita Castro, who fled Cuba decades ago and became a vocal critic of her brother’s regime, expressed disdain for those who rejoiced over his death.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Ukraine Has Made Great Progress, but We Need Our Allies
item.media:description: A ceremony in Kiev this month marking the 83rd anniversary of the famine of 1932-3 in which millions died of hunger.
item.description: Our country’s adolescent democracy needs the support of America — and its new president, the foreign minister of Ukraine writes.
item.dc:creator: PAVLO KLIMKIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Stuck at the Bottom in China
item.description: After decades of breakneck economic growth, the country’s wealth has ceased trickling down, bringing social mobility to a standstill.
item.dc:creator: LIJIA ZHANG

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Fidel in All His Facets
item.media:description: Fidel Castro in his car during an interview with a reporter in 1964.
item.description: It’s feeble for Obama to say history will judge Castro. There’s been plenty of history in Cuba since 1959, much of it deplorable.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
